metadata.sermon_title: The Things That Do Not Exist
metadata.sermon_start_end: Last week my husband and I went to a screening of Sophie Scholl: The Last Days, a film of unforgettable power. Its subject is The White Rose, a small group of German university students, ardent Christians, who resisted the Nazis. Every one of them was captured and executed. [...] I have come by the grace of God with the apostolic message entrusted to me, to declare to you the presence and power of “the God who raises the dead and calls into existence the things that do not exist.” AMEN.!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses sharply on the specific logic of Romans 4:17, particularly the creative power of God's Word (Logos) and the concept of 'reckoning'. It avoids generalities by anchoring the message in the specific paradox of Abraham’s impotence as the ground for God's action.
quotes: The reason for this stands against reason: Abraham is called the progenitor of all people not because of his strength but because of his impotence.
Abraham was not righteous in himself. God reckoned, 'worded,' spoke him into righteousness.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Deepen the 'nowhere else' aspect by further contrasting Paul's specific use of 'logizomai' against other biblical concepts of merit or covenantal faithfulness.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates awareness of the Greek (Logos, Logizomai) and the Old Testament background (Genesis 1, Genesis 15). The connection between the 'deadness' of Sarah's womb and the creative 'ex nihilo' power is well-established.
quotes: Abraham’s body 'was as good as dead because he was about a hundred years old' and he had a wife who was almost as old and had never conceived any children.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: While the linguistic analysis is present, more attention to the specific religious-historical context of the Roman audience and their understanding of 'ancestry' would strengthen the exposition.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: Application is exceptionally concrete and avoids 'general truths'. It addresses the zeitgeist (human potential, biostasis, political violence) and specific historical/cultural examples (Sophie Scholl, Mississippi swimming pool, Khmer Rouge). It avoids moralism.
quotes: Ted Williams became a joke; but which of us can come any closer to preserving life when death comes to pay its call?
The pool, which had always been for whites only, was filled in with dirt many years ago rather than let blacks into it.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application to the 'Church of Scotland' mentioned in the notes is more explicitly woven into the text rather than just the general 'decline'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves fluidly between the narrative of Sophie Scholl, the exegesis of Abraham, and contemporary reflections on Iraq and Cambodia. The hearer is 'expounded' alongside the text.
quotes: Paul links this creation out of nothing with the promise made to Abraham. What does he promise? ... A new humanity.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: The transition from the Mississippi swimming pool back to the final theological summary is slightly abrupt; the 'present of revelation' could be more tightly fused here.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is handled with radical seriousness (the 'deadness' of the human condition, the 'Ordinary Men' example). Redemption is strictly extra nos (God's Word). Gratitude is seen in the 'signs' of the martyrs.
quotes: The Christian view of humanity is tragic.
Abraham’s distinguishing feature: he had no human potential. His human potential did not exist.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' part (the life of the believer as a sign) could be more clearly defined as a response to the Spirit rather than just 'moral inspiration'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon emphasizes the 'lostness' of humanity in time (the cycle of destruction, genocide). However, the 'narrow way' as a specific call to decision or the reality of eternal loss is less prominent, favoring the 'promise' over the 'threat'.
quotes: We are locked into this cycle of destruction.
The old humanity is named Adam and it is imprisoned by Sin and Death.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address more explicitly the responsibility of the hearer to 'answer God's calling' to move from the broad way of 'Adam' to the narrow way of the 'New Humanity'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, linked to the Word of Creation. The sermon is strongly anti-Pelagian, emphasizing that salvation is outside the self. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the Word becoming flesh.
quotes: The Word that comes into the world incarnate as Jesus Christ.
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make the 'One Lord' more central to the 'New Humanity' section to ensure the sermon doesn't drift into a general theology of 'signs'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 2200 words, the sermon meets Dekker's requirement for breadth to achieve depth. It allows space for complex historical narratives to breathe.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: None; the length is adequate for the substance.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong example of proclamatory preaching that takes the 'deadness' of the human condition seriously. It avoids the pitfall of 'human potential' and moralism, focusing instead on the creative power of God's Word. It falls slightly short on the explicit tension of the 'two ways' (Thesis 6), leaning heavily on the objective promise of God rather than the subjective urgency of the hearer's choice. The exegesis is solid but could be more historically situated.
strengths: Radical focus on 'creatio ex nihilo' as a homiletical principle.
Excellent use of concrete, non-religious examples to illustrate the 'misery' of the human condition.
Strictly anti-Pelagian stance consistent with Barthian/Dekkerian theology.
weaknesses: The 'two ways' (Thesis 6) are present in terms of 'lostness' but lack the sharp call to personal/eternal responsibility Dekker envisions.
The connection between the 'signs' (Sophie Scholl) and the 'Word' risks becoming illustrative rather than strictly proclamatory if not careful.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a sermon in the true sense of Dekker’s definition. It successfully recreates the Bible passage into a current, proclamatory word that challenges the zeitgeist of 'human potential' with the 'Word of God'.
